design_intent.player_goal: Secure wireless and mobile endpoints by selecting the right protocols, authentication, and device-management controls.

trap_list.name: Evil twin ≠ rogue AP
trap_list.misconception: Any unauthorized AP is an evil twin.
trap_list.fix: Evil twin imitates a trusted SSID to lure clients; a rogue AP is simply unauthorized (may or may not imitate).

trap_list.name: Deauth is not jamming
trap_list.misconception: Wi‑Fi disconnects must be RF jamming.
trap_list.fix: Deauth/disassoc uses spoofed management frames; jamming is RF interference. PMF helps deauth, not RF jamming.

trap_list.name: Bluetooth spam vs Bluetooth theft
trap_list.misconception: Bluejacking and bluesnarfing are the same.
trap_list.fix: Bluejacking = unsolicited messages; bluesnarfing = unauthorized data access.

trap_list.name: WPA3 is more than ‘stronger encryption’
trap_list.misconception: WPA3 is basically WPA2 with bigger keys.
trap_list.fix: WPA3 adds SAE, requires PMF, and can provide PFS; Enterprise can add 192‑bit mode and stronger key management.

trap_list.name: PSK networks don’t identify users
trap_list.fix: PSK uses a shared secret; Enterprise uses 802.1X + RADIUS + EAP for per-user/device identity and policy.

trap_list.name: EAP methods differ by certificate needs
trap_list.misconception: All EAP methods require client certificates.
trap_list.fix: EAP‑TLS requires client certs; PEAP/TTLS typically use server cert + TLS tunnel; FAST focuses on roaming reauth efficiency.

trap_list.name: Ownership drives control
trap_list.misconception: BYOD, CYOD, COPE are the same in practice.
trap_list.fix: BYOD is user-owned/user-controlled; CYOD/COPE are org-owned and easier to standardize and enforce.

trap_list.name: Location vs location-based policy
trap_list.fix: Geolocation finds a device; geofencing applies rules when crossing boundaries (block, wipe, restrict).

trap_list.name: Remote wipe isn’t guaranteed
trap_list.misconception: Remote wipe alone prevents data loss after theft.
trap_list.fix: Remote wipe needs connectivity; use FDE + strong unlock so offline theft is still resisted.

boss.name: Boss: The Phantom SSID
boss.premise: A roaming employee keeps getting compromised. Diagnose the wireless threat, pick the right Wi‑Fi protections, and lock down mobile controls fast.

mechanics.phase_1: Detect/contain rogue or evil twin behavior.
mechanics.phase_2: Harden Wi‑Fi auth/encryption to remove easy wins.
mechanics.phase_3: Apply device controls that still help when the device goes offline.

constraint_cards.effect: Assume sideloading/jailbreaking attempts; enforce compliance actions.
